cargo-crev-id 0.10.1

This doesn't currently compile. I didn't realize that this change would have to be so large.

I'm not sure how to deal with these traits:
`fn parse(s: &str) -> Result<Self>`
`fn parse_draft(&self, s: &str) -> Result<Self>`

They can't seem to be accessed from a trait object.

@dpc What do you think I should do?

title: Simplify README title and introduction. Added the Features heading.
body:
I think that the README title is currently too complicated. It's trying to explain too much. It contains a hyperlink, brackets, and a forward slash. It also wraps around on my screen.

I think that it should be very simple and easy to consume because it's the first thing that a new visitor will see.


Checklist:

* [x] `cargo +nightly fmt --all`
* [x] Modify `CHANGELOG.md` if applicable

title: Combine push/pull into publish/update
body:
I didn't change `fetch`, because I don't know what are the implications of fetching an URL without trusting it.

Fixes #220

title: Fewer subcommands
body:
```diff 
 SUBCOMMANDS:
-    advise      Create advisory urging to upgrade to given package version
     clean       Clean a crate source code (eg. after review)
     diff        Diff between two versions of a package
     distrust    Distrust an Id
     edit        Edit README.md of the current Id, ...
-    export      Export an id, ...
     fetch       Fetch proofs from external sources
-    flag        Flag a crate as buggy/low-quality/dangerous
     git         Run raw git commands in the local proof repository
     goto        Start a shell in source directory of a crate under review
     help        Prints this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
-    new         Create an Id, ...
+    id          Manage your own Id (create new, show, export, import, switch)
     import      Import proofs, ...
     open        Open source code of a crate
     publish     Commit and Push local changes to the public proof repository (alias to `git commit -a && git push
                 HEAD`)
     pull        Pull changes from the public proof repository (alias to `git pull`)
     push        Push local changes to the public proof repository (alias to `git push HEAD`)
     query       Query Ids, packages, reviews...
-    report      Report that the crate is affected by a certain issue
-    switch      Switch current Id, ...
     review      Review a crate (code review, security advisory, flag issues)
     trust       Trust an Id
     update      Update data from online sources (crates.io)
     verify      Verify dependencies
```

And managing ID is all in one place:

```
SUBCOMMANDS:
    export    Export your own Id
    help      Prints this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)
    import    Import an Id as your own
    new       Create a new Id
    show      Show your own Id
    switch    Change current Id
```

`show` combines `query id current` and `query id own` into one by adding "(current)" annotation. `query` remained unchanged.

title: run_diff: Support non-%PATH% diff from windows git
body:
On Windows, diff is likely available through a git install, but *not* in
%PATH%.  Specifically, the git installer warns that adding *nix tools to
%PATH% will change the behavior of some built in windows commands like
"find", and by default doesn't do this to avoid breaking anything.

title: Pretty print Package[Draft] comments.
body:
I've taken to using:

```yaml
...
comment: |
  Long description
  over multiple lines
  describing my review process
  and resulting concerns/rationale.
```

Using write_as_headerless_yaml turns this into a soup of quoted \ns, which while valid/correct, isn't very readable.  This changes the Display traits a bit to fix that.  On the other hand, maybe it'd be less confusing to keep the quoted style by default / for single line comments...?

title: change trust labels from [high, none, no] to [pass, none, fail]
Don't use ':' in filenames, windows doesn't like them.
body:
I'm not sure if this counts as a breaking change (should I try to keep the original path on !windows?), or if this is even the right place to make this change, or if there's other places that also need fixing, but this at least fixes basic commands like `cargo crev open ...` on windows when source == PROJECT_SOURCE_CRATES_IO == `https:\\crates.io`.  Turns out windows doesn't like `:` in filenames.  If you prefer an alternatives, just let me know.

Checklist:

* [ ] `cargo +nightly fmt --all`
* [ ] Modify `CHANGELOG.md` if applicable

title: Fix windows support for editors with arguments, quotes.
body:
Tested with:
```
C:\>git config --global core.editor "\"%LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe\" --wait"

C:\>type "%USERPROFILE%\.gitconfig" | findstr editor
    editor = \"C:\\Users\\MaulingMonkey\\AppData\\Local\\Programs\\Microsoft VS Code\\Code.exe\" --wait
```
Which works for both git commits and cargo crev editing.

title: A few cosmetic improvements of the Verify Tui
body:
* crates are alphabetically sorted
* numbers of owners and issues are easier to read
* better column widths
* no resize computations when screen didn't change size
* screen is cleared on real resize to avoid artefacts
* mouse wheel scroll

title: Terminal UI for "verify deps"
body:
This new behavior is hidden behind the --interactive flag:

    cargo crev verify -i

The application is always responsive, it can be quited with ctrl-q and the table can be scrolled.

It's not the final state, but it's already usable without (known) regression.

Once it's merged, my intent is to work on those points:

- a bunch of cosmetic and ergonomic improvements
- maybe alphabetical sort of crates by default 
- fuzzy filter/search (similar to broot)
- mouse (and keyboard?) sorting on various columns, hints on column meaning
- comment the code
- an help page
- selection, crate detailed view

And later my hope is that this could be used to launch crate related actions. And of course work on extending the TUI to other problems, like looking at reviews or at the trust trees.

title: Parallelize part of verify deps
body:
It goes from 13s to 5s for the whole program execution on the crev repository.

```
time cargo crev verify deps
real	0m13,009s
user	0m13,105s
sys	0m0,752s

time ../target/release/cargo-crev crev verify deps
real	0m5,069s
user	0m13,192s
sys	0m0,739s

```
Most of the gain comes from executing in parallel the geiger counts.

This PR brings also a big refactoring to separate the verification process from its display (one of the goals being to then improve the display)

title: Mods
body:
The aim is to increase modularity.

By distributing the content of `cargo-crev/src/main.rs` into more focused files we'll make it easier to evolve and maintain the application.

title: Remove extern crates
body:
Remove all `extern crate`s and `use` macros instead. This is how for example `serde` seem to recommend doing it (https://serde.rs/derive.html).

While there, visit all `Cargo.toml` `[dependencies]` and remove what's not used anymore and sort the remaining.

title: Move from `app_dirs` to `directories`.
body:
As `app_dirs` is not maintained anymore (see https://github.com/AndyBarron/app-dirs-rs) and as seen [here](https://github.com/dpc/crev/issues/125) there are some issues with config and cache paths on Windows, we should move to a more maintained alternative.

I would like to propose [`directories`](https://crates.io/crates/directories) which is still actively developed.

This has the following effects:
- On Windows `Dawid Ci,281,,380,arkiewicz` will change to `Dawid Ciężarkiewic`.
- On MacOS `Application Support/crev` will change to `Preferences/dev.Dawid-Ciężarkiewic.crev`.

I did not test it on MacOS, it would be appreciated if somebody did.

Also I removed `APP_INFO` completly, is a global similar to it needed?

Fixes #125.

title: Use to_str instead of as_bytes
body: This is the start of removing platform-dependent API (#81). I have used `to_str` instead of `to_str_lossy` and propagated the errors upwards. The code could be simpler when using the latter, but it's better to err on the safe side.
